content:
• Thursday, October 24, 2013

  • Rising repo rates in China keep Asia on edge

    • Asian stocks trend lower as investors are becoming increasingly concerned about a liquidity crunch in China, despite contentions that the PBOC is simply trying to counteract inflows from abroad.
    • Nikkei -1.2%
    • Shanghai Composite -0.8%
    • Kospi -1%
     
     
     
     
    | 11:34 PM
  • MRTX

    Mirati Therapeutics prices public offering, shares slide

    • Mirati Therapeutics (NASDAQ:MRTX) prices its previously announced public offering at $17.50, a 3.4% discount to Wednesday's close. (8-K)
    • The shares fell 3.6% during Thursday's regular session.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:18 PM
  • BMRN

    BioMarin loss wider than anticipated, shares slip

    • BioMarin (NASDAQ:BMRN) turns in a wider than expected Q3 loss.
    • Revenue growth by product: Naglazyme, +1.1% to $63.2M; Aldurazyme, -1.7% to $23.4M; Kuvan, +19.8% to $43.6M; Firdapse, +13.9% to $4.1M (worth paying attention to for CPRX shareholders).
    • Y/Y widening in adjusted EBITDA loss is attributable to "increased R&D expenses from advancing PEG-PAL, BMN 673 and BMN 701 [and] increased SG&A expenses."
    • "The next major inflection point for the company is the potential market approval of Vimizim in the U.S. and Europe," CEO Jean-Jacques Bienaim√© says. Upcoming events: Ad Com on November 19 and forthcoming CHMP opinion. (PR)
    • BMRN -2.8% AH
     
     
     
     
    | 9:13 PM
  • WDC

    Western Digital -1.2% AH following soft guidance; Seagate up

    • Previously down over 3% in AH trading, Western Digital (NYSE:WDC) has pared its losses after guiding on its FQ1 CC (prepared remarks) for FQ2 revenue of $3.775B-$3.875B and EPS of $1.95-$2.10, below a consensus of $3.88B and $2.18.
    • Investors had already been expecting a tough quarter on account of PC and (in light of EMC's numbers) storage industry weakness. Seagate (NASDAQ:STX) is now up 1.4% AH.
    • WDC estimates hard drive industry shipments totaled 139M in FQ1, up M Q/Q and flat Y/Y. Shipments are expected to be flat Q/Q in FQ2.
    • FQ1 enterprise SSD sales totaled $106M (~3% of revenue). The sTec and Virident deals should boost WDC's flash memory-related sales. WDC's hard drive ASP fell $2 Q/Q to $58.
    • FQ1 gross margin was 29.8%, +70 bps Q/Q. It's expected to be flat Q/Q in FQ2. $150M was spent on buybacks.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:14 PM
  • SYNA

    Synaptics -7.5% AH due to guidance, seasonality blamed

    • Though its FQ1 results topped estimates and the company's raised guidance, Synaptics (NASDAQ:SYNA) is guiding for FQ2 revenue of $192M-$208M (exc. Validity Sensors), below a $209.4M consensus. Y/Y revenue growth is expected to slow to 34%-45% from FQ1's 75% clip.
    • During a brief talk with Seeking Alpha, CEO Rick Bergman attributed the guidance to seasonality; OEMs that have been placing large orders and filled channels ahead of the holiday season are set to pare back orders towards year's end.
    • Several other chipmakers with strong mobile exposure have also issued light Q4 guidance (I, II, III), but Synaptics' big 2013 run-up gives it limited margin for error.
    • Bergman also admits Synaptics, like other chipmakers, is seeing a demand shift towards cheaper smartphones, which in turn can pressure ASPs. But he's optimistic about the ability of early 2014 hardware launches (inc. those at February's Mobile World Congress) to help Synaptics maintain its mobile momentum.
    • Mobile sales totaled $162.7M in FQ1, -6% Q/Q but +152% Y/Y on account of this year's big design wins. PC sales +5% Q/Q and -4% Y/Y thanks to industry weakness. Gross margin was 49.1%, -90 bps Q/Q and +140 bps Y/Y. Opex +19% Y/Y to $62.1M.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:34 PM
  • COG

    Cabot Oil earnings nearly double, production surges

    • Cabot Oil &¬†Gas (NYSE:COG) +1.8%¬†AH after reporting a 91% jump in Q3 earnings driven by a surge in natural gas production.
    • Q3 natural gas production rose 61% Y/Y to 107.1B cf while realized average prices fell 9%; output of oil, condensate and natural-gas liquids rose 43% to 898K barrels as average prices grew 2.4%.
    • COG affirms FY 2014 capex view of $1.375B-$1.475B, and expects to drill 170-190 net wells in 2014, including 130-140 in the Marcellus Shale and 40-50 in the Eagle Ford Shale; mid-point of guidance for 2014 unit costs of $2.65/Mcfe implies more than a 10% drop vs. mid-point of 2013 unit cost guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:16 PM
  • ELY

    Callaway Golf jumps 12% on Q3 beat, guidance raise

    • Shares of Callaway Golf (NYSE:ELY)¬†jump 11.6%¬†AH after the company crushed expectations in Q3¬†and raised guidance.
    • Gross profit margin jumped to 34% from 21% in Q3 2012. Callaway continued to execute on its turnaround effort, with opex falling to $76M (43% of revenue) from $87M (59% of revenue) in Q3 2012.
    • Management hiked full-year guidance to revenue of $836M from $810M-$820M (and vs. consensus of $814.1M) and EPS of -$0.03 to $0.01 from -$0.12 to -$0.04 (and vs. consensus of -$0.07).
    • PR, conference call¬†(replay)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:07 PM
  • CLF

    Cliffs Natural Resources rises on cost cuts, better iron ore prices

    • Cliffs Natural Resources (NYSE:CLF) +1.5%¬†AH after reporting improved Q3 earnings on reduced costs and 17% higher iron ore prices.
    • Q3 revenues per ton rose 2% to $112.67, primarily attributable to higher Y/Y market pricing for iron ore and an increase in pricing for one customer due to the reset of their contract base rate; cash cost per ton in U.S. iron ore was $64.81, down 4% Y/Y.
    • In the Asia-Pacific segment, revenue per metric ton rose 28% to $108.88, thanks to improved market prices and higher-grade ore.
    • CLF expects China to maintain its healthy steelmaking pace, and anticipates demand for its U.S. iron ore and North American coal businesses to remain healthy.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:48 PM | 2 Comments
  • CECO

    Career Education rockets 51% AH on European ops divestment

    • Career Education (NASDAQ:CECO) shares rocket¬†up 51%¬†AH after the company sells its European education business to P-E firm Apax Partners for $305M. CECO closed today with a market cap of $255M. Career Education will receive proceeds of $276.5M from the sale, which is expected to close by the end of the year.
    • European ops generated revenue of $128.6M in 2012, or 9% of the company's total revenue.
    • The company will redeploy capital in its U.S. operations, which have been plagued by collapsing enrollment figures¬†and legal probes¬†over inflated job placement claims.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:47 PM | 1 Comment

  • After-hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: CECO +51.3%.DECK +14.3%.ZNGA +11.7%.ELY +10.2%.MKTO +10.1%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m. QLIK-19.4%.HWAY -17.7%.RMD -11.7%.ECHO -8.3%.BSAC -7.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:45 PM | 4 Comments
  • QLIK

    Tech guidance roundup: Qlik, KLA-Tencor, Freescale, Maxim, CA

    • QLIK expects Q4 revenue of $156M-$161M and EPS of $0.28-$0.31, below a consensus of $165.8M and $0.45. The company says its "continued success in attracting enterprise-level sales opportunities is adding complexity to [its] overall sales process," and is taking actions to correct the issue. Shares -19.4% AH. (Q3 results, PR)
    • KLA-Tencor (NASDAQ:KLAC) expects FQ3 revenue of $670M-$730M and EPS of $0.67-$0.87, below a consensus of $760.3M and $0.96. Shares -2.7% AH. (FQ1 results, PR)
    • Freescale (NYSE:FSL) expects Q4 revenue of $1.03B-$1.07B, below a $1.08B consensus. Several other chipmakers have also issued soft Q4 guidance. Shares -6.8% AH.(Q3 results, PR)
    • Maxim (NASDAQ:MXIM) expects FQ2 revenue of $605M-$635M and EPS of $0.37-$0.41, largely below a consensus of $631.2M and $0.43. Nonetheless, shares +5.7% AH.following a year of underperforming the tech sector. (FQ1 results, PR)
    • CA expects FY14 (ends March '14) revenue to be down 3% to up 2% Y/Y; that's better than a consensus for a 3.9% drop. EPS is expected to be a range of $2.96-$3.03 vs. a consensus of $2.97. Shares +3% AH. (FQ2 results, PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:36 PM
  • AFOP

    Alliance Fiber Optic reverses earlier losses on Q3 results, guidance

    • Alliance Fiber Optic (NASDAQ:AFOP) is making up losses and then some following its Q3 results. Shares were¬†down 6.2%¬†through the close but have climbed¬†up 7.7%¬†in AH trading.
    • Management guided for revenue in Q4 of $21.5M-$23.5M (77%-93% Y/Y growth) vs. consensus expectations of $21.8M. CEO Peter Chang: "With this range of quarterly revenue, we believe we will end the year of 2013 with record slaes and record profits as well."
    • PR,¬†Conference call at 5:30 pm ET
     
     
     
     
    | 5:31 PM
  • NTGR

    Netgear tumbles 7.6% AH after Q3 beat but lower-than-expected guidance

    • Netgear (NASDAQ:NTGR) shares tumble¬†7.6% AH¬†after the company beat estimates in Q3 but issued light Q4 guidance.
    • Gross margin continued falling to 28.9% from 29.8% in Q2 and 31.6% in Q3 2012.
    • Management guides for revenue of $340M-$355M in Q4, well below consensus expectations of $368.7M. Operating margin is seen at 9.5%-10.5%.
    • PR,¬†Conference call at 5pm ET
     
     
     
     
    | 5:05 PM
  • ESRX

    Express Scripts beats on revenue, raises low end of guidance range

    • Express Scripts (NASDAQ:ESRX): Q3 EPS¬†of $1.08, in line.
    • Revenue of $25.92B beats by $910M. (PR)
    • Outlook: FY13 EPS of $4.30-4.34 (versus previous guidance of $4.26-4.34). Q4 outlook: $1.09-1.13/share against consensus of $1.12.
    • Cash flow guidance revised down to $4-4.5B from $4.5-5B due to "delays in certain non-client¬†integration activities."
    • ESRX -2.7% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:01 PM
  • DWDP

    DuPont to spin off performance chemicals unit, shares +3.5%

    • DuPont (DD) +3.5%¬†AH after announcing plans to spin off its performance chemicals segment into an independent, publicly-traded company 100% owned by DD shareholders.
    • The company says the move, which had been sought by Wall Street, will allow it to better focus on the growth area of specialty materials and agriculture.
    • The spinoff is expected to dent Q4 EPS by a cent or two.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM
  • CLF

    Cliffs Natural Resources misses by $0.03, beats on revenue

    • Cliffs Natural Resources (NYSE:CLF): Q3 EPS of $0.68 misses by $0.03.
    • Revenue of $1.55B (+0.1% Y/Y) beats by $70M.
    • Shares +2.4% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:45 PM | 1 Comment
  • RMD

    ResMed falls after earnings, revenue miss estimates

    • Shares of ResMed (NYSE:RMD) tumble 12% AH.
    • The company missed on both lines for FQ1.
    • In general, analysts predicted weak U.S. flow generator growth would be offset by new products, higher gross margins, and a falling Australian dollar. Broadly speaking, here's how that panned out: Revenue up 4% in the Americas; "R&D expenses were favorably impacted by the depreciation of the Australian dollar"; global revenue up 5% on "sales of higher valued flow generators," and the "Quattro Air is on its way to being one of the best mask launches ever [while] The Swift FX Nano ... was just launched in the U.S. in September with good reception."
    • Also: The board declares a quarterly dividend of $0.25. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM
  • DECK

    Deckers Outdoor surges 14% AH on Q3 beat

    • Deckers Outdoor (NASDAQ:DECK) shares¬†surge 13.6%¬†AH after the company beat Q3 expectations handily.
    • UGG brand sales increased 1.3% Y/Y to $337M, Teva 0.6% to $18M, Sanuk 0.5% to $18.4M, and other brands 81.3% to $13.3M (primarily due to the inclusion of HOKA ONE ONE, which was acquired in Sept. 2012).
    • Retail sales increased 34.5% to $52.6M as Deckers opened 37 new stores, and comps grew 1.9%. E-commerce sales expanded 12.2% to $14.9M as the company unrolled international sites.
    • Management guides for Q4 revenue of $706.8M (+14.5% Y/Y) vs. consensus of $703.6M and EPS of $3.66 (+32%, down from previous guidance of 38%) vs. consensus of ¬†$3.88.
    • PR, conference call at 4:30 pm ET
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM | 1 Comment
  • SYNA

    Synaptics beats by $0.08, beats on revenues

    • Synaptics (NASDAQ:SYNA): FQ1 EPS of $1.31 beats by $0.08.
    • Revenue of $222.6M (+75% Y/Y) beats by $3.6M. Shares -7.7% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM | 1 Comment
  • AMZN

    Amazon higher as strong sales trump in-line loss, Q4 guidance wide open

    • Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) grew product sales at a fast clip of 19.6% in Q3, and services sales rose even faster at 45%, but total operating expenses didn't just go away as the company's cost of sales rose 20% to $12.366B during the period.
    • Sales grew 31% for the company's North America segment and 15% for International as the net sales mix moved 3 bps back toward North America.
    • The company sees Q4 revenue of of $23.5B - $26.5B to top its earlier forecast, but with a mid-point below the analysts' consensus estimate of $25.9B.
    • The guidance for Q4 operating income is -$500M to +$500M, a nifty $1B range for a single quarters' worth of sales. (PR)
    • AMZN +6.0% AH to $351.36.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM | 4 Comments
  • CERN

    Cerner drops after top-line miss, tepid guidance

    • Cerner (NASDAQ:CERN) dives 7% AH following a Q3 top-line miss.
    • Bookings hit an all-time high at $928M, up 21% Y/Y.
    • Backlog of $8.4B ($7.63 contract, $769.8M support and maintenance) is up 24% Y/Y.
    • Q4 outlook: $0.38-0.39/share on revenue of $775-815M versus consensus of $0.39/share on $815.81M in sales. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM
  • ZNGA

    Zynga beats Q3 estimates, Q4 guidance light, COO named; shares soar

    • Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA): Q3 EPS of -$0.02 beats by $0.02.
    • Bookings of $152.1M (-40% Y/Y) beats by $8.4M.
    • Expects Q4 bookings of $130M-$140M, below $147.9M consensus. Expects Q4 EPS of -$0.05 to -$0.04, below -$0.03 consensus.
    • Mobile gaming industry vet Clive Downie has been named COO.
    • Shares +11.3% AH. CC at 5:00PM ET. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:10 PM | 17 Comments
  • MSFT

    Microsoft beats estimates, shares rise

    • Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT): FQ1 EPS of $0.62 beats by $0.08.
    • Revenue of $18.53B (+16% Y/Y) beats by $740M.
    • Shares +5.8% AH. CC at 5:30PM ET. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:07 PM | 40 Comments
  • DECK

    Deckers Outdoor beats by $0.23

    • Deckers Outdoor (NASDAQ:DECK): Q3 EPS of $0.95 beats by $0.23.
    • Revenue of $386.7M (+2.7% Y/Y) beats by $0.65M. Shares +3.9% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:01 PM | 2 Comments
  • JIVE

    Jive Software closing higher on Najarian call

    • Jive Software (JIVE +8.4%) spiked higher in afternoon trading, and is closing with big gains, after optionMonster's Jon Najarian made a bullish call on the company, citing strong call-buying activity.
    • The enterprise social networking software firm's Q3 report arrives on Oct. 30. Shares have significantly underperformed the Nasdaq this year.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:00 PM
  • PDS

    Precision Drilling profit falls as North American drilling slows

    • Precision Drilling's (PDS -2.9%) Q3 earnings fell by more than a quarter as drilling activity slowed in North America because of lower customer spending, sending shares sharply lower.
    • Canada's largest oil and gas drilling contractor also cut its 2013 capital costs estimates by C$45M to C$609M.
    • Drilling activity, as measured by drilling rig utilization days, fell 1% in Canada and 11% in the U.S.
    • Barclays says results were well below expectations, but "the issues appear to be largely transitory, [and Q4] appears to be tracking well thus far."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • NTR

    Potash lowers 2013 potash demand forecast

    • In its earnings call, Potash (POT -2.1%) cut its forecast for 2013 world potash shipments to 53M-54M metric ton, down from its previous estimate of nearly 56M metric tons but higher than 2012's 51M; it sees global demand of 55M-58M in 2014.
    • A supply contract between the Canpotex group of North American potash producers and China's Sinofert Holdings likely will be signed in early 2014, according to CEO Bill Doyle.
    • Also, POT does not expect to dip into the debt markets to maintain its dividend program. (Q3 earnings)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM
  • LKM

    NQ calls Muddy Waters allegations "false,"

    • NQ Mobile (NQ -47.2%) has issued a brief statement about the detailed fraud allegations provided in Muddy Waters' report. The Chinese mobile app developer calls the allegations "false," and says it will provide "a more detailed response" before the market's Friday open.
    • Shares remain halted after crashing in response to the report.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 12 Comments
  • PHM

    Homebuilders surge after Pulte and M/I results

    • With interest rates already sharply lower than during Q3, investors look past the slowdown in new home orders last quarter at PulteGroup (PHM +7.6%) . Also reporting today, M/I Homes (MHO +7.6%) records a similar gain after new contracts of 869 homes gained 15% from a year ago.
    • Not unnoticed is the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate falling 15 bps last week to a 4-month low of 4.13%.
    • Other builders: Toll Brothers (TOL +2.5%), KB Home (KBH +2.9%), Ryland RYL, Hovnanian (HOV +2.5%), Standard Pacific (SPF +2.5%).
    • ETFs: ITB¬†+3.1%, ¬†XHB¬†+2.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:47 PM
  • CHK

    Chesapeake moves higher after Citi upgrades shares to Buy

    • Chesapeake Energy (CHK +4%) is on the rise after Citigroup upgrades shares to Buy from Neutral with a $35 price target, up from $27, citing potential growth and cost cutting initiatives.
    • Citi believes the new management "will continue to pursue an aggressive restructuring and cost reduction program while realizing significant efficiency improvements throughout its core regions."
    • Oil production is poised to accelerate, a point that is underappreciated by the market, the firm adds.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:34 PM | 9 Comments
  • VAR

    Varian Medical slips after guiding below the Street

    • Varian Medical (VAR -6.7%) suffers through a rough session after missing on both lines with its Q4 report.
    • The company adjusted its backlog downward by $156M, citing "ongoing uncertainty in the U.S. healthcare environment as well as a higher level of cancellations in the quarter relating to orders from small free standing clinic developers whose projects did not move forward."
    • More specifically, CEO¬†Dow Wilson says U.S. customers are slowing their purchasing decisions due to ambiguity surrounding "the implementation of healthcare reform, cumulative cuts in reimbursements for freestanding clinics, and consolidation of radiation oncology centers." (PR)
    • "Results showed notable deterioration in business trends in the company's U.S. business," Goldman's David Roman notes, adding that even after revising his estimates, the stock still trades at a slight premium to its peer group. Price target lowered to $70 from $74.
    • Outlook: The company sees FQ1 and FY14 EPS of $0.87-0.91 and $4.22-4.34 respectively, against consensus of $0.96/share and $4.48/share.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM
  • FOE

    Ferro +17% after beating estimates, guiding higher

    • Ferro (FOE +17%) shares power higher after the specialty chemicals producer reported better than expected Q3 earnings and revenues and issued upward guidance for the full year (earnings call).
    • Deutsche Bank raises its price target to $12 from $8, citing FOE's cost saving initiatives and value creation strategy gaining traction faster than expected; while Q4 upside will be limited, FOE should recapture business when its eco-friendly plasticizers production facility starts up in H2 2014 (Briefing.com).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:27 PM
  • PRKR

    ParkerVision continues to plunge, down 53% on damages verdict

    • Shares of ParkerVision (OTC:PRKR -53.5%) continue to plunge after trading resumes following a jury award of $173M in its patent lawsuit against Qualcomm.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:15 PM
  • EPRS

    Zalicus rallies as article says shares could triple

    • Shares of Zalicus (ZLCS +23.8%)¬†are up sharply on the session.
    • Helping the cause is SA contributor Jason Napodano, who calls Z160 a "potentially an enormous drug if it works in both PHN and LSR."
    • More specifically, Napodano says positive results from two Phase 2a studies may mean "the drug can ... capture 25% of the market from Lyrica and generic gabapentin [putting] worldwide sales in the area of $1.5B."
    • If we assume $1.5B in sales a decade from now, along with a 30% chance of success and a price-to-sales multiple of three, we get a target price of around $14 after discounting back to the present at 15%, Napodano says.
    • The analyst is looking for data "by the middle of November."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:50 PM | 1 Comment
  • AMD

    AMD higher after high-end GPU launches to good reviews

    • AMD (AMD +2.7%) has officially launched its high-end R9 290X GPU. The first reviews for the chip, which is based on¬† powers graphics cards sporting an MSRP of $549, have been very positive.
    • Tom's Hardware has given the 290X its Elite award; it's the first time a graphics card has been granted the honor. Benchmarks show the 290X beating Nvidia's (NVDA -0.4%) costlier GeForce GTX 780 ($649) and Titan GPUs ($999), and faring very well in multi-monitor tests.
    • Nvidia recently discounted several cheaper cards to counter AMD's aggressive pricing for its new Hawaii GPUs (of which the 290X is the costliest/most powerful). TH: "Nvidia still does thermals, acoustics, and aesthetics better. But now it’s also charging a hefty premium for those luxuries."
    • AnandTech's review of the 290X is also upbeat, but its praise is a little more qualified. "Against NVIDIA’s pricing structure the 290X is by every definition a steal at $549 ... But with that said, although the 290X has a clear grip on performance and price it does come at the cost of power and cooling."
    • Like other Hawaii GPUs, the R290X supports AMD's Mantle API, which the chipmaker promises will deliver an unmatched level of hardware optimization.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:43 PM | 4 Comments
  • PRKR

    ParkerVision falls on $173M jury verdict in Qualcomm suit, shares halted

    • ParkerVision (OTC:PRKR -15.2%) shares plunge after a jury delivers a $173M verdict in favor of the company in its damages trial against Qualcomm (QCOM - unchanged). The sum is a long way off the $432M in infringement damages ParkerVision sought.
    • The jury ruled Qualcomm's infringement of ParkerVision's IP was not willful.
    • Shares are currently halted.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM
  • ICUI

    ICU Medical abandons sale after failing to find buyer: Bloomberg

    • ICU Medical (ICUI -7%)¬†is sharply lower on more than four times its average 10-day volume.
    • Bloomberg says the company has ended its sales process after no buyers emerged.
    • More here
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM
  • NXPI

    NXP soars after results, guidance better than feared

    • NXP's (NXPI +10.1%) Q3 results are mixed, and so is its Q4 guidance: while the midpoint of NXP's EPS guidance range of $0.85-$1.02 is above a $0.92 consensus, the midpoint of a revenue guidance range of $1.189B-$1.256B is below a $1.23B consensus. But with investors expecting bad Q4 guidance from chip stocks, the reaction to NXP's numbers has been quite positive.
    • Likely pleasing the Street: NXP expects its gross margin to rise to 49%-50% in Q4 from 47.8% in Q3, which itself was up 60 bps Q/Q. The chipmaker's Q3 EPS was boosted by $159M in buybacks, as well as by controlling spending: opex only rose 3% Y/Y, less than rev. growth of 7%.
    • NXP's Automotive chip sales rose 9% Y/Y after dropping 3% in Q2. Identification chip sales (inc. NFC chips) remained strong, rising 20% in Q3 vs. 21% in Q2. Industrial/Infrastructure sales saw a big turnaround, +18% vs. -7%. Portable/computing +9% vs. +1%, mixed signal chips +15% vs. +3%. Only standard product (analog chip) sales remain weak, falling 8% in Q3 after dropping 11% in Q2.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:59 PM
  • PVG

    Snapback rally for Pretium after positive results

    • Pretium Resources (PVG +19.4%) claws back a chunk of its large losses this month after reporting positive drill fan results at its Valley of the Kings project in British Columbia. "Reported assays include 12 intersections grading greater than 1K grams per ton gold uncut, two of which were intersected in the planned Program fan."
    • The company was most recently stung on Tuesday by a geologist team asserting there was "no valid gold resource" at the project.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:28 PM | 4 Comments
  • QIHU

    NQ Mobile crashes as Muddy Waters calls company a "massive fraud'

    • Muddy Waters has started coverage on NQ Mobile (NQ -30%) with a Strong Sell; the firm's target price is below $1. (report - .pdf)
    • MW claims at least 72% of NQ's 2012 Chinese security software revenue ($32.2M) is "fraudulent," and that much of it ($20.2M) came from a shell company called Yidatong. The firm says an investigation found Yidatong's offices were "either non-existent or completely empty."
    • MW also declares NQ's third-party payments channel to be "non-existent," and its Chinese payments portal to be "purely cosmetic." It estimates (citing survey data) NQ has only a 1.4% share of the Chinese security app market rather than a stated 55%, and that Qihoo (QIHU -0.5%) dominates the space with a 73.5% share. Also, MW's store checks indicated few phones had NQ's software pre-installed, and that its prepaid card sales were limited.
    • Meanwhile, NQ's apps are declared to be "spyware," and its global app revenue below $1M/year. The company's acquisitions are deemed "highly likely to be corrupt," with ghost addresses uncovered for some of them, and its cash balances "highly likely to not exist."
    • Update (2:01PM ET): The selloff has worsened. NQ now -51.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:19 PM | 56 Comments
  • OPTT

    • Q3 ad sales rose 42% Y/Y, faster than Q2's 35% pace. While Yandex's sites (largely relying on search ads) posted ad sales growth of 33% (down from Q2's 37%), ad network sales growth surged to 82% from Q2's 25%, and display ad sales growth rose to 35% from 31%. Ad network sales now account for 18% of ad revenue.
    • The ad network growth was fueled in large part by the extension of a deal to power paid search results for Russian e-mail site Mail.ru. One downside: the growth led traffic acquisition costs to rise to 24.1% of revenue from 18.9% in Q2 and 18.8% a year ago
    • Overall top-line growth was pressured by the fact online payment commissions nearly evaporated, following Yandex's decision to sell its 75% stake in the Yandex.Money payments JV.
